ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this course, I performed clinical research surrounding ASD. I learned what the day to day of a research fellow and PI were like, and I focussed on how analytical skills could result in qualitative analysis through research.

I became more comfortable in the scientific research and writing process, including formulating hypotheses and designing studies to test them, working in a lab setting and troubleshooting during experiments, writing grant proposals, creating figures and figure legends for scientific papers, writing all aspects of a scientific paper (abstract, significance statement, methods and materials, discussion, ect), and making and presenting scientific research posters at the symposium

This course spanned my second year of working in my lab, and it was an incredibly valuable experience. Not only did I enhance my technical skills in lab, I learned to be a better scientist in terms of interpreting data, troubleshooting, note-keeping, planning experiments, designing/presenting a poster, and writing my thesis. This was one of the greatest academic challenges I've undertaken, but it was worth it!
How to carry out research
how to do a scientific research paper
just doing research

This course was a year long independent research project. I learned how science is done and all the little steps that go into lab work, data analysis, scientific writing and making figures. I have a really strong background in clinical research and feel confident enough to seek work in this field.
I learned essential skills for working in a laboratory along with knowledge on how to write a research paper.
critical scientific thinking skills, techniques to answer basic science questions

I learned about the research process and what it's like to develop a question, hypothesis, and analyze data. It was really cool to get to acquire my own data and look at the results. I also really enjoyed drawing conclusions from the data and seeing what it had to say.
I learned alot with my senior research, I think I lucked out with having such great advisors.

my research project taught me a lot about the methods, patience, and critical thought required for experimental design and analysis of results, as well as how to adapt parameters of the experiment when results were not as expected
Studied CCEPs (cortico-cortical evoked potentials) in Dr. Zaveri's lab
I learned a lot about the research process.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There are no weaknesses! This course allows for senior thesis and research to be conducted harmoniously, and I loved the experience!

Strengths:
- I appreciated how it built over the course of a year so that we had the opportunity to engage in meaningful projects, but that we also had the chance to see many of the steps of the research process
- My PI and mentor were very helpful in providing guidance and feedback throughout each step
- The assignments throughout the year kept me on track and working towards the final goal

Weaknesses:
- I was lucky with my PI and mentor, but I know that experiences can vary since they are very dependent on one's lab and supervisors -- more centralized help and guidance from the department might eliminate some of these issues

Everyone's lab experience will be different, but I can speak to the strong organization of the course itself. The neuroscience faculty made their expectations clear for our senior poster and thesis, and our registrar (Nancy DeSilva) was a wonderful resource. She was beyond helpful and made the workload more approachable.

I feel like we got a lot of information later than we should have, made it difficult to plan. For example, further info on posters was only a week or two before they were due. Info on our time slot for poster presentations was only like 2 days before the presentations.
NA

More direction on finding labs and realistic timelines from the DUS'es. Each project was so different and PI engagement was wildly varied - hard to gauge if I was on track or behind or how the major specific classes related to research project.
Strengths were my post doc and my PI.

I loved my research, I wish that there was more opportunity to engage with the DUS's and with the other students in the course, maybe mid-semester thesis presentations in a Mellon-forum type style may be beneficial

I think a strength was the length in between the things due was great because it kept us on track but also made sure that the assignments were too close to each other. i think a weakness was maybe getting more advice and tips on how to write the paper from the major. There were times when I was unsure if i was doing certain things correctly and maybe having someone who could have read over my thesis (other than a writing tutor) who had a neuroscience background could have been really helpful. That way they could have gave me advice on how to make my paper stronger in a scientific way.

With this course I knew what I was doing since it was my second semester of research so everything went smoothly. I do think that overall with the senior requirement for neuroscience, you are often left to figure everything out for your own and the quality of the experience really depends on how helpful your advisors are. I didn't find much support in the neuroscience department itself.

I loved being able to dedicate significant time to research during my last year at Yale. A weakness would be sometimes deadlines were not well communicated and there wasn't much guidance/support/communication in general throughout the course of the year
NA
This is senior thesis research, which I think is a huge asset to the neuroscience major at Yale. It allows you to do real research for credit and get very involved. Keep this class!!

I love the neuroscience major at Yale because the material is so interesting, but their mentorship is SO DISORGANIZED. I wish I had had more support from the faculty, but honestly, older neuro students were my best resources for choosing classes, finding opportunities, and deciding my thesis topic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are a neuroscience senior, you need to take this course, so yes haha!
Yes, it's a great way to get involved in independent research here at Yale, with a good balance of freedom and guidance. I learned a lot that I will take with me after I graduate.

This course is required for any neuroscience major wanting to earn a B.S., so a recommendation won't carry much weight here, but I will say that this class is WORTH THE WORK. You get out of it what you put in. If you treat it like a wonderful learning opportunity and formative experience, that's what it will become.
Required
make sure u have a good advisor
You have to take it
Yes, it was necessary as I prepare to graduate.

I think this is a great opportunity to have a research experience but you don't receive much help from the departments itself especially when it comes to initially finding a lab. As a first generation college student I didn't know that I was expected to be looking for a mentor years in advance and it's a shame that isn't common knowledge. I got lucky finding a open spot and having great advisors within the lab.
I would recommend this course to another student as it is required as a senior requirement, the research project will really depend on your mentor
Yes, for neuro req
You have to take it for the major, but it is also a great opportunity for learning and growth.
